Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: NSF CAREER Proposal Writing Workshop for Early Career Professionals; Charlotte, North Carolina; August 23, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for a CAREER proposal writing workshop that will be held concurrent with the American Society of Mechanical Engineers annual design conference. Approximately 200 young faculty will attend the workshop, which will last a full day. The workshop will enable young faculty to better frame their research and to write higher quality proposals. This will lead to better research, more effective teaching and more effective use of NSF funds.

This workshop will be conducted on August 23, 2016, in Charlotte, North Carolina. The workshop agenda includes a session on proposal writing best practices, presentations by previous CAREER awardees, and a session of framing research hypotheses and broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this workshop was to provide PhD students, postdocs, and early career faculty in the engineering design community with a specific forum to learn and discuss best practice for preparing an NSF CAREER proposal. A second goal of this workshop is to encourage interaction between junior and senior faculty and strengthen the community bonds by providing a forum to discuss career development and planning. This objective was met by discussing best practices and success stories, and highlighting the perspectives of reviewers and program directors. The workshop was held at the 2016 ASME IDETC/CIE in Charlotte, NC on Wednesday, August 24, 2016 from 9:00 am – 1:30 pm at the Charlotte Convention Center.

 

Such a workshop is necessary because CAREER proposals are inherently different from general unsolicited proposals to a NSF program, and those preparing to submit a CAREER must consider
1) how their proposed efforts relate to their overall career vision, 2) how such a proposal should be structured, 3) how to make the right connections that support the proposal, and 4) how to incorporate feedback from previous panels. Winning a CAREER award provides significant financial support for young faculty that allow them to accelerate the development of their academic careers as teacher-educators while building a foundation for a lifetime of research contributions. The CAREER award also supports research that explores the challenges associated with 21st century engineering design problems.

 

Speakers at the workshop included two NSF program directors - George Hazelrigg (Deputy Director, CMMI) and Richard Malak (ESD/SYS). Dr. Gul Kremer (Iowa State University), Dr. Jeff Rhoads (Purdue University), and Dr. Babak Heydari (Stevens Institute of Technology) also spoke and gave their perspectives on how to write an effective CAREER proposal. From this workshop, participants gained 1) a better understanding of how to craft a research hypothesis and objective in terms of their career goals,
2) knowledge of how to balance the educational and research aspects of the CAREER proposal, 3) an understanding of best writing practice, and 4) an understanding of how to incorporate reviewer feedback. Thirty-two junior faculty and twenty-three Phd and Postdoctoral students attended the morning workshop session.

 

A lunch was held from 12 pm – 1:30 pm where workshop attendees interacted with senior faculty from the engineering design community. Eleven senior faculty attended this event, joining the 55 attendees. From survey responses after the event, 80.00% of the respondents strongly agreed that they participated in meaningful conversations, 73.33% of the respondents strongly agreed that they interacted with a senior faculty they had previously not interacted with before, and 93% at least agreed it was an effective use of their time. Further, all respondents felt that they received useful career advice.
